name: Adams National Historical Park
description: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesmen, philosophers…and learned women” whose ideas and actions helped to transform thirteen disparate colonies into one united nation.
shortDescription: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesmen, philosophers…and learned wome...

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is open 11:00 am to 4:00 pm Mondays through Fridays. The Visitor Center is closed Saturdays and Sundays. The Visitor Center is closed on wintertime federal holidays, except for Presidents Day.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Entrance into the historic homes at Adams National Historical Park requires an entrance pass. Entrance passes cost $15 per person. Children under the age of 16 are free. If you have an America the Beautiful Interagency Pass, you do not need to pay the entrance fee. Guided tours must be reserved in-person on the day of your visit at the park’s visitor center.

climate.weatherDescription: Be prepared for hot, humid weather during the summer months. The historic homes are not air conditioned. While the visitor center remains open all year, the historic homes are generally closed from approximately November 1 through April 30. Winters in New England often feature low temperatures and snowy/icy conditions. Please exercise caution when visiting the park. The Visitor Center may close during inclement weather.

images.title: The John and John Quincy Adams Birthplaces
images.altText: The Birthplaces of Presidents John Adams (right) and John Quincy Adams (left)
images.caption: The Birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams sit right next to each other on Franklin Street.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.altText: A New England "salt-box" style home with wooden siding and trim.
images.caption: The house where John Adams was born in 1735.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.altText: A New England "salt-box" style house with light gray siding and a beige door.
images.caption: The house where President John Quincy Adams was born in 1767.

images.title: Old House at Peace field
images.altText: A view of Old House at Peace field
images.caption: Old House at Peace field, where four generations of the Adams family lived from 1788 to 1927.

images.title: The Paneled Room
images.altText: The Paneled Room located inside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Paneled Room greets everyone who enters Old House at Peace field.

images.title: The Stone Library
images.altText: The Stone Library located outside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Stone Library houses up to 14,000 books belonging to the Adams family.

images.title: Inside the Stone Library
images.altText: A dark room with tiled floor, filled with chairs and desks, with books lining the walls.
images.caption: A view into the Stone Library

images.title: The Gardens Located at Old House at Peace field
images.altText: The gardens located at Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The gardens located by Old House at Peace field bloom in every color you can imagine.
